file_content.text: We managed to raze the base. They're sending resupply convoys now.
Move a muscle, Captain Biron, and you will be shot. Take his weapon.
Is this how the Republic treats its allies? You have more in common with the Sith than you realize.
I had no knowledge of this plan, Captain, but once begun, it would be suicide not to follow it through in all its aspects.
I initiated the plan. It was self-preservation. You would have betrayed us.
It was necessary.
Another captain, perhaps. I had no such intentions, nor the manpower to do so effectively.
Sergeant Katcho remembers you as a treacherous snake, Biron. Remember him?
Credit our Sergeant Katcho.
Ah, so this is petty revenge.
It's more about not taking chances with dangerous opponents.
Dangerous. You tell yourself that. You honor nothing and reward betrayers, just as the Sith do.
Take him away. And gag him so he can't listen to the sound of his own voice.
He's only complaining because he couldn't betray us first.
I have no sympathy for them.
Betray you? What good would that have done us? Another costly fight when we're at less than half strength?
Your words mean little at the moment, prisoner. Take him away.
That was unpleasant. I never got the impression he was as sadistic as the other Imperials.
He would have turned on you in a second.
Believe it.
It is one thing to know that intellectually, and another to believe it with the whole heart.
But we have defeated the Hailstorm Brotherhood today and acquired a valuable Imperial captive. It's hard to be sour with that.
I delivered both the Hailstorm Brotherhood and the Imperials to you in one move. Appreciate it.
We won. Be happy.
Indeed, thank you. Using our valuable captive, we can force concessions from the Imperials.
He seemed genuine.
I'm having second thoughts.
Don't worry about him now. When we get information out of him, he'll be traded back to his people soon enough.
And with the casualties we inflicted on Biron's soldiers, his outpost is ready to be taken. This is quite a day for the Republic.
I heard about the situation over the comm. Master Sav is dead and half the Brotherhood tried to flee by jumping off the cliff.
A well-executed plan. Of course, the irony is that with the Brotherhood gone, we'll be free to focus our tactics on one another.
What would you suggest, Lieutenant? A twenty-four-hour truce as we return to our outposts?
I could grant that when it involves my men. I cannot, of course, speak for others. What do you think?
If you ever need to defect, you know who to call.
Farewell, Captain.
A fine compliment--but after today's negotiations, I will likely be watched carefully.
Yes, you risked much by coming here, Captain. If only more Imperials were like you.
He's got twenty-three hours and fifty-nine minutes to go. Get moving.
Time's wasting.
Point taken.
I look forward to never seeing him again.
Get him out of here.
Yes... the feeling is mutual.
Farewell, Captain Biron. If only there could be more Imperials like you.
Be careful what you wish for, Lieutenant.
Well. The day's not over yet, and already you brought about the end of the Hailstorm Brotherhood.
There's a bigger war out there on the ice, and for once, the Imperials aren't the worst of it.
Just point me to where I can help. I'm getting used to the cold.
Then where's the big fight?
I never thought we'd see the day the Imperials were second on the list.
The pirates are really worse?
Me neither.
I'm here for my own reasons, Lieutenant.
I've got things to do.
Understood. But there's a lot of good you could do out there.
Admiral Revald commands the Republic fleet on Hoth. From the surface, no less. He's fighting tooth and nail with the White Maw leaders every day.
If you can do for him what you did for us, the White Maw could be a thing of the past. And we would all sleep easier.
Major Vinson at Cresh Base has been sending us messages on the priority frequency, but they're too garbled to decode.
I'd swing by there in case it's a real emergency.
We lost contact with Aurek Base. If they've been offline this long, I can only imagine they'd need help worse than we did.
Well. The Hailstorm Brotherhood's come to an end, and we have no other crisis breathing down our necks. I almost feel relaxed.
It's been an honor to serve with you. Be careful out there.
Our scouts say the Brotherhood is bandaging up. We need to hit them now.
If the remainder of their force is grouping at the ice fortress, they've been badly hurt. It's time to finish them.
The captain's right. We're not going to get this chance again.
I'm not giving this group a centimeter of purchase. They're all going down.
Let's get them.
I can do that.
All right. Our priority target is Master Sav. A cult without its beloved leader is a beast without its head.
I don't like the idea of taking out every last one.
I don't butcher.
I agree, it's not practical. We should aim to stop Master Sav. Without his leadership, the cult would be a disorganized mess.
Sav is a legend among the Brotherhood. We stranded him in the snow once and left him for dead in wampa country.
He strangled one with a tauntaun femur and skinned it with its own claws. He showed up in the ice fortress weeks later, quite alive.
Getting rid of him sounds like a plan.
Take out the leader. Got it.
I won't give him a chance. Now what do I have to do?
Talk about the mission.
We'll need you to spearhead the team eliminating Master Sav--others will secure the turrets and the perimeter.
The ice fortress will be swarming with Brotherhood. We'll have the teams meet up again in the audience hall.
I'll remember that story next time I'm a wampa.
That's a stupid story.
The point is, Master Sav is not to be underestimated. We'll need you spearheading the attack on him while we secure the fortress.
We will split into multiple squads, then meet up again in the audience hall.
Be warned, the hall is a defensible area--they'll move the big guns there once they know we're attacking.
I'll get them out of commission so the rest of the men can work.
I'll remove them.
Hiding behind their hardware will not avail them.
Faith in weapons won't help.
Just in case, you'll have backup. Meet up inside with Sergeant Ennlicher and Sergeant Katcho.
Nothing like artillery to get the blood pumping.
I'll take them out.
With all of us coming down on them, they're in for some bad times.
They won't stand a chance.
Undoubtedly. Meet with Sergeants Katcho and Ennlicher inside the fortress.
Done.
All right. We'll monitor the situation from here. Meet up inside with Sergeant Katcho and Sergeant Ennlicher.
Their men will reinforce you as you push to the audience hall.
If I end up as a pair of smoking boots, I'd just like to say, "I told you so."
It's never easy, is it?
You'll be backed up by Sergeant Katcho's men and Sergeant Ennlicher's from the Imperial side.
If they can't get you to Master Sav in one piece, no one can.
Go quickly. Let's not give them time to get back on their feet.
You did it! I haven't seen that many dead Brotherhood since we first came to the planet.
Agreed. It was efficacious.
I'll assume that was the Imperial equivalent of enthusiasm, Captain.
It was. My scouts are in pursuit of the fleeing Brotherhood now. We'll see what they find.
Now is not the time to underestimate them.
Wise plan.
My thoughts exactly.
They're on the run. What could your troops possibly learn?
An empty gesture.
We know we hurt them; the question is, is it enough to prevent future attacks?
What's the follow-up?
Now we maintain our truce until we determine if our knockout blow was delivered. My scouts should report in at any moment.
Snow Raptor, this is Hatchling. Come in, Snow Raptor.
Go ahead, Hatchling.
We've spotted the remainder of the enemy force entering the ice fortress. Coordinates attached.
Get that flare flying. We'll see if the Imperials pick up their end of the bargain.
I conferred with every man in the platoon. Even if we sent everyone we have, we couldn't strike the Brotherhood effectively.
Then you see my point. A combined operation might have a chance--you didn't say you had visitors.
What are you doing here? We haven't seen a new face in weeks. How did you make it past the Hailstorm raiders?
Who is this and why isn't he in chains?
You first.
I have no idea who you're talking about.
Make it past who?
Then you are lucky not to have encountered them in the passes. The Brotherhood are White Maw pirates, the worst of the lot.
What's an Imperial doing here?
Captain Biron is here attempting to solve a mutual problem--a group of White Maw pirates called the Hailstorm Brotherhood.
They are savages, frankly. Cultists and marauders from some other ice planet that came to Hoth to test their limits.
They hunt and murder those who cannot survive in the cold as they do. Republic and Imperials alike.
If you came to talk, talk.
Then say your piece, Imperial.
My men are in the same situation as Lieutenant Kieral's; cut off with no resupply possible.
Go on.
The Brotherhood don't dare attack us in our outposts, but they're devastating to anyone out on the ice.
That means our supply convoys are constantly being intercepted. It won't be long before they starve us out.
Captain Biron came with an offer--that we join forces long enough to defeat the Brotherhood.
Are you sure we can trust him?
That's too convenient.
What are you thinking? Nobody's worse than the Imperials.
Get rid of him!
I'll take that as a compliment. But the Hailstorm Brotherhood have proven otherwise, with acts too depraved to list.
The Brotherhood have cut our outposts' resupply lines and are picking off anyone that ventures into the snow.
If we don't join forces, they'll whittle us down until we leave our outposts in search of food. Then we die.
How does that compare to being betrayed at some critical point by the enemy?
Imperial "help" is no better.
Without help, our deaths are a certainty. Anything is better.
I don't like it, but I gather neither of you do, either. What's our plan?
If you say so.
What we need is for someone to bait a trap. If we fire a distress flare out on the ice, the Brotherhood will come running to attack.
When that happens, my squad can surround them and wipe them out. All the bait would need to do is last until they arrive.
The Brotherhood will find I am not easily overcome.
I can do that.
They rely on surprise and savagery. Without the former, they can be killed like any other barbarians.
If these fanatics are truly such a plague, I will stop them however I can.
I will do this.
Your valor is appreciated, Master Jedi. It takes a strong heart to volunteer for such a duty.
I'll do it. But make sure you show up fast. I work quickly.
I'll be your bait.
I serve with disciplined men. We will be on time, no sooner, no later.
Feels a little like pushing me overboard and saying all I have to do is swim.
This is nuts, but I'll do it.
I hadn't thought of you volunteering, but we welcome the help.
Have no fear. My men are eager for payback. When the Brotherhood comes, the Empire will be hot on their heels.
Then it's agreed. Here is the distress flare and directions. Find a good, vulnerable-looking spot in the snow.
You'd better show up.
I assure you, if I wanted to ambush the Republic, I've already had plenty of opportunity.
Here's the distress flare. Fire once if all is as planned, twice if the Imperial help isn't enough.
Good luck out there. The Brotherhood knows that ice better than their own backsides.
I'm not fond of this "get myself surrounded by Imperials" plan. And you shouldn't be, either.
No way. [Refuse quest]
Then I suggest you leave, Captain Biron. Your welcome is wearing thin.
Allow me to stay and make my case, Lieutenant. It would be my shame if the Brotherhood took your head simply because I argued poorly.
The Imperials have tricked us too many times for me to fall for this one.
That's a trap. [Refuse quest]
Then our options are limited. We shall see how long we can last.
It's alright. He's with me.
